intro: Hieracium laevigatum subsp. flocciparum, commonly known as the woolly hawkweed, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows in grasslands, meadows, and disturbed soils, reaching heights of up to 30 centimeters. The plant features a basal rosette of hairy, spoon-shaped leaves and produces yellow flowers in a single head at the end of each stem. Its flowers are surrounded by a dense, woolly involucre, giving it a distinctive appearance. The species is characterized by its soft, hairy foliage and is often found in open, sunny habitats.
